*Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365.raw_text: *Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365 Mass. 320, 327 (1974)
*Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to Plaintiff’s minor son to exercise **reasonable care and supervision** while he was participating in the after-school program. See *Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365 Mass. 320, 327 (1974) (duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury to invitees and those entrusted to care).
*Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365.case_name: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston
*Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365.support_reasoning: The case deals with a landowner’s duty to an employee of an independent window‑washing contractor on its premises. The court states the club owed the plaintiff the same duty it owed its own employees: to disclose hidden or concealed defects of which it knew or should have known. It does not concern minors, after‑school programs, or a broader duty of ‘reasonable care and supervision’ for persons entrusted to care; its duty discussion is limited to premises‑liability style duties to warn of hidden defects, not supervisory obligations over activities.
*Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was the employee of an independent contractor working on the club’s premises. The club thereby owed him the same duty it owed its own employees — to disclose hidden or concealed defects on the premises of which it was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care.” (365 Mass. at 327–28)

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 697.proposition: Defendant also owed a duty of care arising from its express and implied representations that children in its care would be properly supervised. *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 697 (2000) (liability arises when one undertakes to render services necessary for the protection of another and fails to exercise reasonable care).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 697.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio is about negligence, causation, and statutory liability involving a scaffolding collapse on a construction site. It does not discuss duties arising from express or implied representations that children (or anyone) in another’s care would be properly supervised, nor does it articulate the Restatement-style principle about undertaking to render protective services. The case actually resolves the matter on lack of causation and never reaches or develops a duty theory like the one stated in the proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 697.relevant_excerpt: “Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. See St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 615, 622-623 (1992) (employer of independent contractor not liable for harm caused to another by independent contractor’s negligence, unless employer retained some control over manner in which work was done).”

*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that entities responsible for the custody of minors have a duty to provide reasonable supervision to protect those minors from foreseeable harm. See *Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8 (1991); *Morash & Sons, Inc. v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 612 (1973).
*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).support_reasoning: The case expressly refuses to recognize the very duty the proposition describes. The court holds that a parent hosting (or supervising) a teen party does not owe a duty of care to protect third parties from harms caused by minors’ drinking, even when the parent knows or should know alcohol will be consumed. Rather than affirming a general duty of reasonable supervision for entities responsible for minors, the opinion limits such duty and extends the Langemann rule to parents present at the party.
*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “We said, ‘We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available.’ … We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here… We conclude that summary judgment for the defendant was correctly ordered in both cases.”

*Morash & Sons, Inc. v. Commonwealth*, 3.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that entities responsible for the custody of minors have a duty to provide reasonable supervision to protect those minors from foreseeable harm. See *Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8 (1991); *Morash & Sons, Inc. v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 612 (1973).
*Morash & Sons, Inc. v. Commonwealth*, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with governmental/sovereign immunity and the Commonwealth’s liability for creating or maintaining a private nuisance that injures neighboring real property. It does not involve minors, custody of minors, or any duty of supervision, nor does it articulate or apply a standard of care toward children. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that entities responsible for the custody of minors have a duty to provide reasonable supervision to protect them from foreseeable harm.
*Morash & Sons, Inc. v. Commonwealth*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e do so now to the limited extent of holding that the Commonwealth is not immune from liability if it creates or maintains a private nuisance which causes injury to the real property of another. We reach this conclusion because what we said about municipalities applies with equal force to the Commonwealth: ‘Public policy in a civilized community requires that there be someone to be held responsible for a private nuisance on each piece of real estate….’”

*Addy v. Boston Herald\u2013Traveler Cor.proposition: Such omissions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law. See *Addy v. Boston Herald–Traveler Corp.*, 358 Mass. 450, 453 (1970) (negligence is failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonable person would exercise in like circumstances).
*Addy v. Boston Herald\u2013Traveler Cor.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses whether Roy was negligent and defines negligence only implicitly through factual application, not by articulating a general black-letter definition. There is no language stating that negligence is ‘failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonable person would exercise in like circumstances,’ nor does the court frame its analysis as a general definitional rule of negligence. The proposition attributes a generic definition of negligence to Addy that does not appear in the quoted text and is therefore not supported by this case.
*Addy v. Boston Herald\u2013Traveler Cor.relevant_excerpt: “The jury could infer that Roy in providing an unsafe method of loading or in participating in the use of an unsafe method failed to exercise the degree of care required under the circumstances. Failure to use preferred methods of operation and violation of accepted trade practices warrant a finding of negligence.”

*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions were the **proximate cause** of J.J.’s injuries. *Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 104–105 (1978) (foreseeability of harm defines scope of duty and causation).
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses proximate cause in terms of foreseeability and explicitly applies that standard to the defendant’s conduct and the third party’s intervening negligence. The court holds that the intoxicated seaman’s operation of the forklift did not break the causal chain because such misuse was reasonably foreseeable, and concludes that a jury could find the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the defendant was responsible. This directly supports citing the case for the principle that foreseeability of harm defines the scope of duty and proximate causation.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’… Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Under *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 52–54 (1983), institutions entrusted with students or children are liable for failing to implement reasonable safeguards against foreseeable harm.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent focusing on causation, not duty, so it does not itself articulate the rule about institutional responsibility for student safety. However, the majority opinion in Mullins (at 52–54) is well-known and frequently cited for recognizing that a college has a duty to exercise reasonable care, including implementing reasonable security measures, to protect resident students from foreseeable criminal acts. Thus, while the excerpted dissent does not support the proposition, the case as a whole (in the cited pages of the majority) does.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: Because the excerpt is solely from the dissent on the issue of proximate cause, it does not contain the majority’s articulation of the duty of institutions to implement reasonable safeguards against foreseeable harm to students. The majority’s discussion of that duty appears elsewhere in the opinion (389 Mass. at 52–54), which is not included in the provided text.

*Goodrow v. Lane Bryant, Inc.*, 432 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act was a substantial factor in causing J.J.’s concussion, emotional distress, and resulting medical and economic losses. *Goodrow v. Lane Bryant, Inc.*, 432 Mass. 165, 173 (2000).
*Goodrow v. Lane Bryant, Inc.*, 432 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion in Goodrow v. Lane Bryant concerns overtime pay, executive exemption status, calculation of overtime under Massachusetts wage law, and treble damages. It does not involve any facts about J.J., a concussion, emotional distress, or causation of medical or economic losses, nor does it discuss substantial factor causation in a tort context. The proposition attributed to Goodrow is therefore unrelated to the case and is a mis-citation.
*Goodrow v. Lane Bryant, Inc.*, 432 Mass.relevant_excerpt: Goodrow commenced a class action against Lane Bryant, Inc., for failing to pay overtime compensation at the rate of one and one-half times her hourly rate for the hours she worked in excess of forty in any work week... The judge correctly concluded that Goodrow was not employed as a bona fide executive at Lane Bryant and thus was not exempt from the overtime provisions of G. L. c. 151, § 1A.

*Thibeault v. Poole*, 283 Mass. 480 (193.proposition: Plaintiff, as parent and guardian, is entitled to recover for medical expenses, lost wages, and the pain and suffering of his minor child resulting from Defendant’s negligence. See *Thibeault v. Poole*, 283 Mass. 480 (1933).
*Thibeault v. Poole*, 283 Mass. 480 (193.support_reasoning: The case concerns a husband’s right to recover consequential damages (medical and hospital expenses) for injuries to his wife, not a parent’s right to recover for a minor child’s injuries. It also makes clear that the parent’s (or spouse’s) consequential claim is separate from, and dependent on, the injured person having a viable cause of action; it does not authorize recovery for the child’s pain and suffering by the parent. The opinion references parent–child actions only by analogy and confirms that the personal injury claim (including pain and suffering) belongs to the child, while the parent’s claim is limited to consequential expenses and related losses.
*Thibeault v. Poole*, 283 Mass. 480 (193.relevant_excerpt: “The same principle applies in general to an action by a father to recover expenses incurred by him in the care of his minor child injured through the tortious act of a third person. The action for personal injuries belongs to the child, but the action for consequential damages to the parent. Duffee v. Boston Elevated Railway, 191 Mass. 563. McGreevey v. Boston Elevated Railway, 232 Mass. 347. Slavinsky v. National Bottling Torah Co. 267 Mass. 319, 322.”

G.L. c. 223 \u00a71.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223 §1 because the acts and omissions giving rise to the cause of action occurred in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 218 \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218 §19 because the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 231 \u00a785.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated G.L. c. 231 §85 (comparative negligence framework), but Plaintiff’s minor child was not negligent and bears no comparative fault.

G.L. c. 231 \u00a76D.proposition: Plaintiff seeks recovery pursuant to G.L. c. 231 §6D for personal injuries caused by negligence.

G.L. c. 231 \u00a76F.proposition: Award costs and fees pursuant to G.L. c. 231 §6F and any other applicable provisions of Massachusetts law;
